description: From Middle English from (“from”), from Old English from, fram (“forward, from”), from Proto-West Germanic *fram, from Proto-Germanic *fram (“forward, from, away”). Cognate with Old Saxon fram (“from”) and Old High German fram (“from”), Danish frem (“forth, forward”), Danish fra (“from”), Swedish fram (“forth, forward”), Swedish från (“from”), Norwegian Nynorsk fram (“forward”), Norwegian Nynorsk frå (“from”), Icelandic fram (“forward, on”), Icelandic frá (“from”), Albanian pre, prej. More at fro.

entries.meaning: Used to indicate source or provenance.
examples: Paul is from New Zealand.
I got a letter from my brother.
You can't get all your news from the Internet.
This manuscript is from the 1980s.

definitionGroups.group: Used to indicate a starting point or initial reference.

entries.meaning: Indicating a starting point in time.
examples: The working day runs from 9 am to 5 pm.
Tickets are available from 17th July.

entries.meaning: Indicating a starting point on a range or scale.
examples: Rate your pain from 1 to 10.
Start counting from 1.

entries.meaning: Indicating a starting point on an array or gamut of conceptual variations.
examples: You can study anything from math to literature.

entries.meaning: With reference to the location or position of a speaker or other observer or vantage point.
examples: It's hard to tell from here.
Try to see it from his point of view.
The bomb went off just 100 yards from where they were standing.
From the top of the lighthouse you can just see the mainland.

entries.meaning: (MLE) Indicates a starting state of the predicament of the subject. Synonym of since being
examples: I’ve been doing this from pickney.

entries.meaning: (mathematics, chiefly Britain, not in formal use) Denoting a subtraction operation.
examples: 20 from 31 leaves 11.
She was barred from entering.
A parasol protects from the sun.
Your opinions differ from mine.
He knows right from wrong.

entries.meaning: Produced with or out of (a substance or material).
examples: It's made from pure gold.

entries.meaning: Used to indicate causation; because of, as a result of.
examples: Too many people die from breast cancer.
